nodes.text: An IoT based home automation system can provide low-cost, wireless remote control of household appliances, improve energy efficiency and accessibility, and be scalable and secure
The proposed system design integrates firmware for smart control with minimal human interaction to automate home electrical devices
An Android application acts as client using socket programming to send commands in two modes: switch mode (radio buttons) and voice mode (microphone -> Google servers -> parsed string)
Hardware components used or specified include Arduino UNO R3, Bluetooth module HC-05, relay module, printed circuit board, wires, power supply, and WiFi connectivity

Prototype implementation features a wireless remote switching system controllable via smartphone app, supports voice commands, displays device status, and provides an indoor WiFi range of approximately 150 feet
The system is designed to be controllable by any WiFi-capable device (Android, iOS, PC) to provide flexible remote access
Control communications are implemented over secure channels, described as SSL over TCP or SSH, to protect remote appliance control
Related work demonstrates feasibility of IoT-based smart home controllers using microcontrollers, MQTT brokers, voice assistants, and Raspberry Pi servers for automation and security
Home automation systems can reduce energy waste caused by users forgetting to turn off devices and can assist elderly and disabled users who have difficulty with manual controls
A practical limitation to broad adoption is that complexity and cost factors can prevent users, especially in emerging markets, from embracing home automation systems

Conclusion: The developed prototype demonstrates feasibility of a low-cost, wireless IoT home automation system that is economical, expandable, shows required functionality (remote switching, voice control, status display), and can improve access and energy performance while requiring further attention to complexity and adoption barriers
